update-log-entry.description:
In my excitement to post my first tutorial a few weeks ago, I neglected to mention something.
When you're doing any sort of image replacement or using an icon font you'll want to include labels for accessibility reasons.
If you take a look at the code for our social icon links, you should notic
update-log-entry.title: Getting More Social (Follow-Up)

update-log-entry.description:
I used to drink coffee all the time. I could finish most, make that all , of a pot by myself. That was just at breakfast. I'd look for any excuse to have a cup. Looking back at it now, I might say it was an addiction.
Recently I started cutting back, hard . Not just on coffee, but a lot of things
update-log-entry.title: I love coffee

update-log-entry.description: There was an article in Businessweek recently about a young woman who would manually send upwards of 500 faxes, yes faxes , per week. The sheer volume is amazing in this age of email and instant communication. The article goes on to describe how one of her coworkers demonstrated their process for c
update-log-entry.title: They Live!

meta-content.meta-content:
Not really, but she does give me the idea she thinks I have self-esteem issues.
My oldest daughter is two, almost three years old. Like most kids her age, she enjoys drawing and painting and playing with Legos. She likes reading, dolls, and stuffed animals, but her favourite thing is solving jigsaw puzzles. I've watched her countless times, and she can assemble every one she has, only five or so right now, all by herself. I don't mention this because I'm proud of that fact, which I am, but because whenever she asks me to do them with her, she acts as if she's clueless as to how they're put together, or even what the end result is supposed to look like.
I must admit that at first I found this a bit odd and also a bit frustrating. It then occurred to me that maybe it's the interaction she craves. She can do the puzzles by her self, but she wants some time with daddy. I can understand that. I didn't get much time with my father, and I want to be there for my kids as much as possible. But, *I'm also a bit neurotic*, and when she hands me a piece and asks, "where's this go?", or she applauds after I find two pieces of a puzzle that fit together and exclaims, "OH, LOOK A COW!", I start wondering, does she think I need this?
Earlier, while she sat on the couch, I was straightening her play-room. I stopped for a minute, lost in thought, planning my next angle of attack, and she jumped down, ran over to me and gave me hug that seemed to say, you poor, poor man. This isn't an everyday occurance but it happens enough to make me think. Which is not always a good thing. It doesn't help either when she randomly asks me why I'm sad. How does someone respond to that question from someone who should just be started to get a grip on her own emotions.
Most of the time she seems happy and full of life. And after being at home with her, just the two of us, for the past year I know we've gotten close. Maybe she's seeing something that I don't, or the things that are small to me are the world to her. I am normally pretty considerate and empathetic, and as my wife has mentioned to me, it could just be that she is as well. For example, someone could cough or sneeze and she'll call out from the next room with completely genuine concern, "ARE YOU OK?"
Maybe sometimes she is worried about me, but if so, it shows she cares. I'd like to think we're pretty close, and I hope we stay that way.

Not really, but she does give me the idea she thinks I have self-esteem issues.
My oldest daughter is two, almost three years old. Like most kids her age, she enjoys drawing and painting and playing with Legos. She likes reading, dolls, and stuffed animals, but her favourite thing is solving jigsaw puzzles. I've watched her countless times, and she can assemble every one she has, only five or so right now, all by herself. I don't mention this because I'm proud of that fact, which I am, but because whenever she asks me to do them with her, she acts as if she's clueless as to how they're put together, or even what the end result is supposed to look like.

First one is probably going to be crap, but it teaches you what you need to know to build the next one better.
At least with cooking, even the crap ones can still turn out tasty.

website.description: Personal website for web person, Paul Dukes.
